Award.AwardTitle: The Long Term Effects of Animal Introductions on the Ecology of Central New Mexico

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Emily Lena Jones, of the University of New Mexico, will investigate changing social-environmental networks in the Middle Rio Grande region of New Mexico between AD 1300 and 1945. When Coronado led an expedition of Spaniards into New Mexico in 1540, he entered a complex socioenvironmental network in which indigenous communities worked with (and occasionally against) each other to survive in an environment characterized by unpredictability, variability, and patchy resources. This Prehispanic system (documented through a variety of archaeological work as well as through Spanish documents) was fundamentally altered by the biological agents the Spanish brought with them (domestic plants and animals from Spain) as well as by cultural agents (global trade networks, the mission system, the Spanish colonists themselves). This alteration, famously dubbed the "Columbian Exchange" by Alfred Crosby (1972), had ramifications across the globe and set the stage for the world in which we now live. In particular the research will provide insight into the factors which shaped and continue to affect Southwestern USA environment today. This has the potential to develop effective management tools. The project will also provide educational and training opportunities for students.

In this project, Dr. Jones and University of New Mexico archaeology students will analyze fauna from archaeological sites to assess changes in people's use of animal resources in central New Mexico from the late Prehispanic period (ca. A.D. 1300) through the early 20th c. Activities will combine identification of archaeofaunal collections with analysis of carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen bone isotopes to (1) establish a baseline diet for central New Mexico in the late Prehispanic period; (2) understand the nature and timing of the adoption (and eventual dominance) of introduced animals of Spanish origin, namely domestic sheep, cattle, and pigs as well as the replacement of the region's Prehispanic domestic taxon, the domestic turkey; and (3) test for evidence for widespread environmental change resulting from the introduction of domestic taxa of Old World origin to central New Mexico. This project will therefore make use of existing collections to contribute new data to significant questions in archaeology, environmental history, and ecology. Dr. Jones and students will add primary data (both archaeofaunal and isotopic) relevant to a variety of disciplines to the record, allowing other large-scale landscape analyses to take place.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this project, Dr. Emily Lena Jones, of the University of New Mexico, investigated changing social-environmental networks in the Middle Rio Grande region of New Mexico between AD 1300 and 1945. When Coronado led an expedition of Spaniards into New Mexico in 1540, he entered a complex socioenvironmental network in which indigenous communities worked with (and occasionally against) each other to survive in an environment characterized by unpredictability, variability, and patchy resources. This pre-Hispanic system (documented through a variety of archaeological work as well as through Spanish documents) was fundamentally altered by the biological agents the Spanish brought with them (domestic plants and animals from Spain) as well as by cultural agents (global trade networks, the mission system, the Spanish colonists themselves). This alteration, famously dubbed the "Columbian Exchange" by Alfred Crosby (1972), had ramifications across the globe and set the stage for the world in which we now live.

 

Between 2017 and 2020, Dr. Jones and University of New Mexico students, both graduate and undergraduate, analyzed fauna from 5 archaeological sites to assess changes in people's use of animal resources in central New Mexico from the late pre-Hispanic period (ca. A.D. 1300) through the early 20th c. This work has established a baseline diet for central New Mexico in the late pre-Hispanic period; clarified the nature and timing of the adoption (and eventual dominance) of introduced animals of Spanish origin, namely domestic sheep, cattle, and pigs as well as the replacement of the region's pre-Hispanic domestic taxon, the domestic turkey; and has established that, while the environmental impacts of colonization can be seen from the very earliest days of Spanish presence in central New Mexico, widespread environmental change resulting from the introduction of domestic taxa of Old World origin seems coincident with Anglo-American settlement in the nineteenth century and the coming of the railroad. Seven University of New Mexico students received advanced training in zooarchaeological analysis over the life of this award (two undergraduate and five graduate students); three undergraduate students contributed to the project as volunteers; and an additional 13 students (four graduate and nine undergraduate) engaged with the project as part of the 2020 Spring Zooarchaeology class at the University of New Mexico. This project has thus not only contributed to our understanding of the Columbian Exchange in New Mexico, highlighting the role of continental connectivity in environmental change; it has supported the education of the diverse student body of the University of New Mexico, engaging students from tribal, Hispanic, and other communities historically underserved by science.

 

Project results have been presented to the professional community at the Society for American Archaeology Meetings in 2018 and 2019, the European Association of Archaeologists annual meeting in 2018, the Great Basin Anthropological Association meeting in 2018, and the XX Congreso Nacional de Arqueología in Córdoba, Argentina; to the public in numerous events including the Snead-Wertheim annual lecture at University of New Mexico in 2018; and in a set of publications (including several co-authored by University of New Mexico students). Additional publications, including two book projects and multiple journal articles, are expected in the coming two years, as are additional public presentations.
